H0.text: The direction he ran and the average speed are the additional information Stephen needs to calculate his acceleration during his 12‑second run across a grass field.

H1.text: The distance he ran and the average velocity are the additional information Stephen needs to calculate his acceleration during the run, which took him 12 seconds across a grass field.

H2.text: The beginning speed and the direction he ran are the additional information Stephen needs to calculate his acceleration during the 12‑second run across the grass field.

H3.text: The beginning velocity and the ending velocity are the additional information Stephen needs to calculate his acceleration during his 12‑second run across a grass field.

A5.text: In mechanics, acceleration is the rate of change of the velocity of an object with respect to time.

A6.text: If there is a change in speed, direction or both, then the object is said to be undergoing an acceleration.

A7.text: The average velocity of an object over a period of time is its change in position, Δs, divided by the duration of the period, Δt.
